title: Krodua chief pledges land for youth to cultivate cocoa
text:
8 August 2015 23:00 CET Krodua chief pledges land for youth to cultivate cocoa By GNA 
Akyem Krodua(E/R), Aug. 8, GNA - The Chief of Krodua , a farming community near Asamankese, Nana Kwame Anim, has pledged 500 acres of land to support the Ghana Cocoa Board Youth in Cocoa Project. 
He made the pledge when the Public Affairs Manager of the Board, Mr Noah Amenyah called on him at his palace at Krodua to thank him for his earlier offer of 60 acres to support the project when the National Service Personnel of Cocoa Board Association organised a sensitisation durbar at the community to mobilise the youth to go into the cultivation of cocoa. 
Nana Anim said , few day after his announcement to support the project , three youth approached him for land to cultivate cocoa and so he allocated two acres each to the first two and five acres of land to the third youth who has started working on the land. 
He said, it his desire to transform the economy of his community by the next four to five years so that the youth from the area, who have left to Accra and other urban areas would come back to work to facilitate develop faster. 
He appealed to the Board to help provide computers to the school in the community to enable the youth to gain competence in ICT. 
Mr Amenyah on behalf of the Management of the Board expressed appreciation for the Chief's support of the project. 
He explained that, the Board launched the project because most of the cocoa farmers in the country are elderly people, hence the need to encourage the youth to invest in the industry to sustain it. 
He said the project is receiving tremendous support and youth in Senkyem, near Assin Foso have also mobilised and established a cooperative of about 11,000 young people. 
Mr Amenyah said another group of about 8000 youth have also formed groups in Elubo and New Adubon. 
He said this year, the Board supported the project with 50 million cocoa seedlings which was distributed free to the farmers and said next year, there are plans to nurse 60 million seedlings for the project. 
GNA
